title: Can the artificial intelligence be more intelligent than people? If yes how and when? - Quora

response.answer_text: Are you more intelligent than your neighbor? How do you prove it? What about you being more intelligent than an Australian aborigene? How do you justify your statement? There is no proof or justification about you being more intelligent than anybody (or less intelligent, for the sake of argument). There is no Fundamental Theory of Intelligence to explain how and why you are like that compared with any other person. Such Theory should explain also why animal intelligence cannot process abstractions and it has instincts instead of free will (like we humans have, and that is what pushes us to think humanly). As long as we do not have it (THE Theory) we cannot IN ANY WAY simulate/emulate/create Artificial Intelligence, the one real, on par with human one. Machine learning/deep learning do NOT processes abstractions, but symbols. Symbols are weak replacements for concrete notions. We can use ML/DL, but these technologies are not AI, but PI - PseudoIntelligence. Do you know what Pseudo means in Greek? Or maybe SynthI, meaning that we take parts of human/natural intelligence and digitize them, fusing them together. It is the equivalent of chymera - another term from Greek mythology, a monster made of different parts, each from a different animal. And Pseudo/Synthetic Intelligence cannot in ANY way become more intelligent than us humans, because it is a fake intelligence. It needs us permanently, programmers that make and control the algorithms ( they can improve the parameters of the processes, but not turn to other processes to control them; for example DeepWhatever from Google was able to beat human champion at Go, an ancient and difficult game, but it is totally unable to do it for any other game. True, it did it again for some strategy game multiplayer, but it needed human intervention for that, certain reprogramming, some changes. Or a human does not need that - and even more, a human can deal with ANY kind of data as input, while such programs need specific, precise data, or else… All these arguments disqualifies the so-called AI of today as Artificial General Intelligence, that one on par with HI, HumInt…

Yes. AI may not be more intelligent than some people but it can be more intelligent than many. It already happened. A simplified version of how intelligence operates would include the comprehension of several variables or factors, their correlation or interaction, and inference making. All these operations require maintaining information in the memory. In these logistic operations and memory retention AI beats most people. For example in the hospital intensive care units an APACHE II scoring system has been in use for a few decades now. With input of many pieces of information on a patient’s vital sign and physiological function APACHE II generates a score reflecting the severity of the patient’s disease and his risk of death. The score is used to guide clinician’s management of the patient. An advantage of this system is that it can do its job consistently from patient to patient, which even skilled human beings don’t always do.

When you have a child you teach/train her. Can she become more intelligent than you? Yes. Because she will have access to the brain network (culture/society/world) and learn from multiple sources and multiple brains. In short, you give her your personal knowledge then she keeps learning from the network without your participation. With AI everything gets more complicated. It is like a child that has to be trained forever and the attempts to connect it to the network so far failed miserably as it got totally confused in the infinite world of human perceptions. AI can be intelligent only in anything it was trained on, no more, no less. Can we create a network of AIs where they can train each other without our participation in the future? Time will tell.

Sigh.. That old nonsense word again! The word "intelligence" with its many and varied shades of meaning, is the greatest contributer to the woolly-mindedness which plagues discussions of this kind. It is usually associated with vague anthropocentric notions of our species representing the pinnacle of evolution to which all others, in some equally vague sense strive. We need to talk instead in terms of skill-sets or behaviors. Machines have long been far smarter than us at certain tasks. Raw numerical computation, The most intricate data processing system on the planet, the Internet, has surpassed us already in a lot of respects and can be soon be expected to be the predominate cognitive entity,

Many people seem to think that if computers become powerful enough they’ll eventually work just like a human brain (for better or worse). They fail to appreciate how completely and fundamentally different the two things are. Our human noggin contains an extremely complex organ which evolved over 300,000 years and governs a behavior optimized for survival and reproduction. As well, our newborn brain still needs over twenty years of worldly experience just to understand other humans and attain some basic common sense. We acquire our highly flexible intelligence by interacting with the world as a human being. No computer can ever do that. Current developments in AI aren’t showing any progress in a biological or general type of intelligence beyond a very low level. The top researchers are saying that even a primitive AGI is a long way off and it’s unknown how it would ever compare to human intelligence. No one really knows what computers will be doing in one hundred, fifty or even ten years. All we can say for sure is it will be distinctly non-human.

Not in the near future. But, there are more probabilities that it will happen. The developments of AI in different fields are quite imbalanced. Many experts have predicted that, in time, AI will exceed Human Intelligence (HI); however, there is no solid consensus among them. Moreover, the controversial issue of how to adequately define AI and HI has made it difficult to answer this question.

If you define intelligence as the ability to heuristically learn and store new information, it is almost here. If you’re looking at the ability to heuristically connect and find patterns in unrelated information bits, this is still under development. What is here today? The ability to perform facial, fingerprint, DNA and voice pattern recognition is already here and about 95–99% accurate. You will see more and more security upgrades in everything from cell phones to military-grade vaults hit the marketplace, but you will also see new AI hacking software being used by the criminal community as well.

Not yet. You can get some good answers with AI but certainly not as good as a knowledgeable person. At the moment AI is more like a computerized encyclopedia. Probably some time in the next 50 to 75 years. Remember, the goal is not, “pretty smart” but more intelligent than an expert person in several fields.

As cars and airplanes surpass human abilities in speed or height, and fire in warmth, electricity in light, computers in accuracy — A.I. and robots are excellent in their respective areas, but they still remain tools. Humans are the best in the areas in which we are most fully human. In this sense, A.I., robots, computers, and other devices are liberating us to be more fully human.
